questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to severe right flank pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting for the past 2 hours. The pain is 7/10 in severity and radiates to the groin. Medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is unable to lay still and is agonizing with pain. A urine dipstick is positive for blood. She is treated with IV fluids and analgesia. Further evaluation will most likely reveal which of the following set of findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with the classic signs and symptoms of nephrolithiasis, including flank pain radiating to the groin, nausea and vomiting, hematuria, and inability to lay still. In the absence of underlying conditions or additional clues, it is reasonable to deduce that the patient’s symptoms are due to the most common type of renal stone, calcium oxalate stones.  

Calcium oxalate stones account for 80% of all stones. Idiopathic hypercalciuria is the most common metabolic abnormality in patients with calcium kidney stones. Idiopathic hypercalciuria is characterized by normocalcemia and hypercalciuria that cannot be explained by another medical condition (e.g. hyperparathyroidism). Calcium oxalate stones are not pH-dependent, unlike other stone types. Additional risk factors for developing calcium oxalate stones are listed in the table below.



Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: These findings can be seen in patients with hereditary cystinuria, an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in the proximal convoluted tubule cystine-reabsorbing transporter. This defect also results in poor reabsorption of the amino acids ornithine, lysine, and arginine (COLA). Hexagonal-shaped cystine crystals can be found on urinalysis. Cystine stones account for approximately 1% of all stones. Patients often have a positive family history and present during childhood with recurrent kidney stones.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) stones, which account for 15% of all stones. Struvite stones can be found in the setting of infection by urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Enterobacter. Urease breaks urea into ammonia and alkalizes urine (high pH). This patient has no history of urinary tract infections.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with uric acid stones, which account for 5-10% of all stones. Dehydration, acidic urine, and increased uric acid levels, such as in the setting of myeloproliferative disorders, promote their formation. They can also form in the setting of chronic diarrhea, in which bicarbonate is lost via stool; the subsequent decrease in urine pH facilitates the formation of insoluble uric acid crystals. This patient has none of these conditions.
❌ :
Incorrect: Calcium phosphate stones, which are associated with a high urinary pH (>6.5), are the second most common type of kidney stone. In contrast, calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stone and the most likely diagnosis in this patient. These stones are associated with hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, and hypocitraturia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man undergoes hemorrhoidectomy under spinal anesthesia. The next day, he begins experiencing worsening lower abdominal discomfort. The patient has not urinated since the procedure. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a palpable bladder 4 cm above the symphysis pubis. Urinary catheterization drains 900 mL of urine from the bladder. The patient is treated with a drug that directly increases detrusor muscle tone. This medication acts by binding to which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
This patient likely received bethanechol, a direct muscarinic agonist commonly given for postoperative urinary retention.

Medications that directly act on muscarinic or nicotinic receptors are called direct cholinomimetics. These medications exert their effect by mimicking acetylcholine, which is the neurotransmitter that normally binds to nicotinic and muscarinic receptors. Examples of such medications include bethanechol, carbachol, methacholine, and pilocarpine.

The effects of each medication in this class differ depending on which muscarinic receptor subtypes it interacts with. The receptor subtypes and their characteristics are detailed in the following table:
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors:
Incorrect: This patient likely received bethanechol, a direct muscarinic agonist commonly given for postoperative or postpartum urinary retention. Bethnecol does not act on nicotinic receptors.  
✅ Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alpha-1 receptors:
Incorrect: Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists help relieve the mechanical obstruction associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia. It achieves this function by relaxing the smooth muscle at the bladder neck and prostatic capsule. It does not act on the detrusor muscle.  
❌ Beta-3 receptors:
Incorrect: Sympathomimetics (e.g., mirabegron) act on the beta-3 receptor, causing relaxation of the detrusor smooth muscle and leading to increased bladder capacity. These medications are used in the management of urinary incontinence, not retention.  
❌ Histamine-2 receptors:
Incorrect: H-2 receptor blockers (e.g. cimetidine) reduce gastric acid secretion and can alleviate gastroesophageal reflux. These medications do not act on the detrusor muscle.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to a primary care clinic to evaluate urinary symptoms. The patient has been experiencing trouble initiating urination for the past four weeks. The patient has also noticed a poor urinary stream and often felt the bladder was not empty.  A review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 158/89 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Digital rectal examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The patient is started on prazosin. The receptor that this drug works on is attached to which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with obstructive lower urinary tract symptoms, and physical examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth prostate. He most likely has benign prostate hyperplasia. The patient is started on prazosin, which is an α1-adrenergic receptor antagonist. This receptor is coupled with the Gq protein.  

Alpha-adrenergic receptors, ɑ1, and ɑ2 receptors activate when stimulated by catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine, norepinephrine). Together, they help to trigger the fight or flight response. ɑ1-receptors are mainly found in the body’s smooth muscles (in the blood vessels, bladder, and other hollow organs) and are stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system. This receptor is coupled with a Gq protein, bound to guanosine diphosphate (GDP) at rest. When an ɑ1-receptor binds a catecholamine, the receptor changes its shape and allows the Gq protein to release GDP and bind guanosine triphosphate (GTP) instead, thereby activating it. This process then triggers a cellular response that leads to smooth musclecontraction.Ɑ1-adrenergic receptor antagonists can inhibit the activation of these receptors (e.g., prazosin, doxazosin, tamsulosin), thereby causing vasodilation and relaxation of the hollow organs (e.g., urinary bladder).  

Option Analysis

✅ G protein with q polypeptide (Gq):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ G inhibitory protein (Gi):
Incorrect: The G inhibitory protein (Gi) is coupled with the α2-adrenergic receptor. Activation of Gi leads to negative feedback on the effects of G stimulating protein (Gs). In contrast, prazosin acts on α1-adrenergic receptors.  
❌ G stimulating protein (Gs):
Incorrect: The G stimulating protein (Gs) is coupled with β-adrenergic receptors, activation of which causes stimulation of various organs of the body (e.g., heart, kidney, skeletal muscles). However, prazosin does not affect β-adrenergic receptors.  
❌ Protein kinase A:
Incorrect: Protein kinase A is an intracellular receptor protein activated by cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). cAMP is produced when β-adrenergic receptors and the coupled G stimulating proteins (Gs) are activated. Prazosin does not affect β-adrenergic receptors.  
❌ Adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: Adenylate cyclase is a cellular enzyme that is activated when β-adrenergic receptors and the coupled G stimulating proteins (Gs) are stimulated. Prazosin does not affect β-adrenergic receptors.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of severe left flank pain for the past week. The pain has an intermittent squeezing quality, radiates to the groin, and is associated with nausea and vomiting. The patient does not have abdominal pain or fever.  Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows severe left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness and urine dipstick reveals microscopic hematuria. Urinalysis shows crystals in the shape of an envelope. The patient is started on a medication that decreases urinary calcium excretion. Which of the following segments of the nephron is affected by this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with flank pain, hematuria, and envelope-shaped stones on urinalysis most likely have calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis. Thiazide diuretics decrease calcium excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and are an effective treatment option for prevention.

Thiazides inhibit sodium chloride transport by apical Na-Cl cotransporters by competing for a chloride site on the transporter, in the early segment of the distal convoluted tubule. Although thiazides inhibit the reabsorption of sodium in this segment, they increase the reabsorption of calcium. Moreover, calcium reabsorption is also increased along the proximal tubule as a result of reduced extracellular fluid volume, which enhances proximal reabsorption. 

In addition, thiazides are also known to decrease serum magnesium levels. Hypomagnesemia has been suggested to result from potassium deficiency, increased passive magnesium secretion, or decreased active magnesium transport in the distal convoluted tubule. 

Loop diuretics, on the other hand, can cause hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia by decreasing the electrical gradient for magnesium and calcium reabsorption and increasing urinary magnesium and calcium excretion.   

Option Analysis

❌ A :
Incorrect: Acetazolamide works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, blocking NaHCO3, and water reabsorption and resulting in urinary bicarbonate wasting. It does not decrease urinary calcium excretion. 
❌ B:
Incorrect: The descending loop of Henle carries fluid from the proximal tubule to the ascending loop of Henle. It allows reabsorption of water into the interstitial fluids to produce concentrated urine. No known drug effectively acts on this segment of the nephron. 
❌ C:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter and can cause hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia by decreasing the electrical gradient for magnesium and calcium reabsorption and increasing urinary magnesium and calcium excretion. 
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ E:
Incorrect: Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act on the collecting duct systems. They do not affect urine calcium excretion.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the office due to issues with urination, which have been ongoing for the past year. He has experienced urinary frequency and urgency but has not had pain with micturition. He also has occasional headaches but is otherwise healthy. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. Family history is essential for prostate cancer in his grandfather. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Digital rectal examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The rest of the physical exam is noncontributory. Urinalysis results are shown below. The patient is started on tamsulosin for management of his symptoms. Which of the following best describes the effect of tamsulosin in this patient?  

 Laboratory Value  Result
 Urinalysis
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Glucose  negative 
 Blood  negative 
 Leukocyte esterase  negative 
 Nitrites  negative 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf

choices.text: Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  No change  No effect
Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  Decrease No effect
Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  Decrease  No change  No effect
Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  change No change  Decrease  No effect
Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  No change  Relax

questions.solution:
This patient has irritative symptoms (urinary frequency, urgency), and physical examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, smooth prostate with a rubbery texture. These findings are suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). He is prescribed tamsulosin, an ɑ1-adrenergic antagonist, to treat his lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).  

ɑ1-adrenergic antagonists are mainly used to improve bladder outlet obstruction by relaxing smooth muscles in the bladder sphincter, prostate capsule, and prostatic urethra. Tamsulosin, however, is different from other drugs in this class (doxazosin, prazosin, terazosin) in that it specifically acts against α1A and α1D receptors (subtypes of alpha-1 receptors) found in the smooth muscle of the bladder neck and prostate. It does not affect ɑ1-receptors in peripheral blood vessels and cannot treat hypertension. Moreover, the medication is known to cause relaxation of the iris dilator muscle and is associated with intraoperative floppy iris syndrome (IFIS).  

Option Analysis

✅  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  No change  No effect :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  Decrease No effect :
Incorrect: ɑ1-adrenergic antagonists (e.g. prazosin) play a major role in the relaxation of the bladder neck, prostate capsule, and prostatic urethra. These medications can also relax vascular smooth muscle and decrease blood pressure. In contrast, tamsulosin is a selective ɑ1a-receptor antagonist that acts on only the bladder neck muscles. As a result, tamsulosin would not cause a decrease in blood pressure.
❌  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  Decrease  No change  No effect :
Incorrect: Finasteride, a 5ɑ-reductase inhibitor, decreases the prostate volume by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It also helps decrease the LUTS in benign prostatic hyperplasia. However, this patient was started on tamsulosin, which does not affect prostate volume.
❌  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  change No change  Decrease  No effect :
Incorrect: This patient was started on tamsulosin, which is a selective ɑ1a-receptor antagonist that acts on only the bladder, neck muscles. As a result, tamsulosin would not cause a decrease in blood pressure.
❌  Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)  Prostate Volume  Blood Pressure  Detrusor Muscle  Decrease  No change  No change  Relax:
Incorrect: Muscarinic antagonists (e.g. oxybutynin) inhibit the M3 receptors on the detrusor muscles, thereby causing muscle relaxation and preventing urinary incontinence associated with an overactive bladder. However, this patient was started on tamsulosin, which does not affecting detrusor activity.

questions.text:
A 75 year-old African-American male comes to the office because of continuous dribbling of urine which began one month ago. In addition, the patient endorses difficulty initiating and maintaining a urinary stream. Past medical records indicate that he has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 150/86 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 15/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are non-contributory. Digital rectal exam reveals an enlarged, symmetrical, and smooth prostate. Laboratory study results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Glucose  118 mg/dL 
 HbA1c  6.9% 
 Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)*  3.6 ng/ml 
*Normal PSA < 4.0 ng/ml

Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s urinary symptoms?

choices.text: Non-neoplastic hyperplasia of the prostate gland
Compression of the urethra by a malignant mass

questions.solution:
This patient has overflow incontinence. The condition presents with straining to void, poor urine stream, and urine dribbling secondary to a distended bladder. Conditions that cause detrusor hypocontractility (e.g., multiple sclerosis, diabetic neuropathy), bladder outflow obstruction (e.g. BPH), and medications (e.g. anticholinergic agents) can result in overflow incontinence. The patient’s age and presence of a smooth, enlarged prostate on physical exam suggest benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) as the underlying cause.  

Diagnosis involves obtaining a postvoid residual volume, which shows how much urine remains in the bladder after an episode of voluntary voiding. This can be done using ultrasound or bladder catheterization.  

Medications are the first-line treatment option. They include agents that reduce urethral closing pressure/bladder outlet resistance (e.g, prazosin, terazosin) and agents that increase detrusor contractility (e.g, bethanechol). In acute settings, intermittent self-catheterization can be utilized to empty the bladder and prevent urinary stasis/infection.  

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired detrusor contractility :
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can cause autonomic neuropathy and a hypoactive detrusor muscle. Although this patient has diabetes, his HbA1c and blood glucose level indicate that his condition is well-managed. Moreover, the finding of a symmetrically enlarged prostate during physical exam suggests that benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) is a more likely explanation for his urinary symptoms.  
✅ Non-neoplastic hyperplasia of the prostate gland:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Compression of the urethra by a malignant mass:
Incorrect: Prostate cancer may obstruct the urethra and cause overflow incontinence. The patient’s age (age > 50 years) and African-American race place him at increased risk. However, his normal prostate-specific antigen and physical exam showing a smooth, symmetric prostate are inconsistent with the presentation of prostate cancer. On board exams, prostate cancer presents as a nodular and asymmetric prostate. 
❌ Urethral sphincter dysfunction:
Incorrect: Urethral sphincter dysfunction causes stress incontinence, which presents as urinary incontinence triggered by events that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., laughing, sneezing, coughing). In contrast, this patient’s symptoms of increased strain, weakened urine stream, and continuous dribbling of urine are more consistent with the presentation of overflow incontinence. 
❌ Infection of the urinary tract:
Incorrect: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) can cause bladder irritation and urge incontinence. Patients with this condition often have a sudden urge to urinate, resulting in involuntary expulsion of urine. This is inconsistent with the patient’s symptoms. Moreover, patients with a UTI would be expected to have additional symptoms such as fever or dysuria.

questions.text:
A 55 year-old female comes to her outpatient physician because of urinary incontinence. The patient reports a sense of fullness in the bladder and continuous dribbling of urine over the past two months. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. However, the patient reports being inconsistent in taking her medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 158/91 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Physical exam reveals decreased sensation to soft touch and pinprick in the distal arms and legs. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Glucose  167 mg/dL 
 HbA1c  8.1% 
 Postvoid residual volume   170 ml 

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Impaired parasympathetic innervation of the bladder
Impaired sympathetic innervation of the bladder
Peripheral vascular disease causing reduced blood supply to the urethra
Abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina
Pelvic floor musculature weakness causing hypermobile urethra

questions.solution:
This patient has overflow incontinence secondary to diabetic neuropathy. To understand the mechanism behind the patient’s condition, it is important to first understand urinary tract and pelvic physiology.  

The bladder is connected to the urethra via the urethrovesical junction. At the junction are two sphincters, the internal sphincter which is regulated by the autonomic nervous system, and external sphincter which is regulated by the somatic nervous system.  

Neurological control of the bladder and internal urethral sphincter is provided by both the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system. Sympathetic signals ensure continence by preventing detrusor muscle contraction and promoting internal sphincter contraction (increases bladder outlet resistance). In contrast, parasympathetic signals promote micturition by inducing contraction of the detrusor and relaxing the internal sphincter.    

Another line of regulation involves controlling blood flow to the urethra. Increased urethral blood flow increases intraurethral pressure, ultimately preventing urine loss.    

In this vignette, the patient has poorly controlled diabetes that has caused somatic and autonomic neuropathy. The patient’s symptoms of suprapubic fullness, continuous dribbling of urine, and increased postvoid residual volume are consistent with those of overflow incontinence. This condition would manifest if parasympathetic signals had difficulty reaching the bladder or urethra, resulting in a lack of detrusor contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation.    

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired parasympathetic innervation of the bladder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Impaired sympathetic innervation of the bladder:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms of overflow incontinence such as bladder fullness, continuous dribbling of urine, and an ultrasound showing an increased postvoid residual volume. The sympathetic nervous system prevents micturition by contracting the internal urethral sphincter and relaxing the detrusor. As a result, reduced sympathetic innervation would cause increased detrusor activity and reduced sphincter tone, resulting in symptoms more consistent with those of urge incontinence.
❌ Peripheral vascular disease causing reduced blood supply to the urethra:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can lead to peripheral vascular disease. In healthy patients, increased blood supply to the urethra increases intraurethral pressure and prevents urinary loss. In contrast, reduced blood flow would cause a decrease in intraurethral pressure, ultimately causing symptoms similar to those seen in stress incontinence.
❌ Abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina :
Incorrect: This describes a vesicovaginal fistula. In patients with this condition, urine from the bladder can pass through the fistula and leak into the vagina, resulting in continuous incontinence. Having an elevated postvoid residual volume or sense of pubic fullness would be atypical in patients with a vesicovaginal fistula.
❌ Pelvic floor musculature weakness causing hypermobile urethra:
Incorrect: A hypermobile urethra can cause stress incontinence. This is because increases in abdominal pressure will be transmitted more to the bladder and less to the urethra. As a result, pressure within the bladder will exceed that within the urethra, resulting in urine expulsion. Stress incontinence typically presents as loss of urine with activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, laughing), which is inconsistent with this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 58 year-old female comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of urinary leakage that has persisted for several months. The patient reports that these episodes occur when she coughs or sneezes. She denies dysuria or urgency. Past medical history is notable for 4 spontaneous vaginal deliveries and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is currently taking metformin. Speculum exam reveals atrophic vaginal walls. Testing with a Q-tip is positive. Bladder postvoid residual volume is 50 ml and her most recent HbA1c was 6.8%. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Infection of the urinary tract by gram-negative bacteria
Hypermobile urethra secondary to pelvic floor muscle weakness
Abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina
Excessive urine production secondary to osmotic diuresis

questions.solution:
This patient has stress incontinence, which presents as urinary incontinence triggered by events that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing, laughing). A common cause is a hypermobile urethra, which causes increases in abdominal pressure to be transmitted more to the bladder and less to the urethra. As a result, pressure within the bladder will exceed that within the urethra, resulting in urine expulsion. Other causes of stress incontinence include weak pelvic floor muscles and reduced urethral sphincter tone.  

Stress incontinence can be diagnosed by performing a history & physical exam. During the physical exam, urethral mobility can be assessed using a Q-tip. In addition, a bladder stress test, which involves observing for urine leakage while the patient coughs or performs the Valsalva maneuver, can be done. A urinalysis can help rule out UTIs, and an ultrasound can measure the post-void residual volume. Urodynamic studies, which involve using a small catheter to fill the bladder, are more invasive and reserved for unclear/complex cases.  

Lifestyle and behavioral modifications, including weight loss, caffeine restriction, and strengthening of pelvic floor muscles via Kegel exercises, are the first-line treatment. Vaginal pessaries, devices that restore normal anatomy by physically elevating the urethra, can be utilized in female patients. If the aforementioned conservative methods fail, surgical intervention such as placement of a midurethral sling may be necessary.  


Option Analysis

❌ Infection of the urinary tract by gram-negative bacteria:
Incorrect: This describes a urinary tract infection (UTI), which may cause urinary incontinence. UTIs can range from being asymptomatic to causing fever, dysuria, and urge incontinence. However, this patient’s history of urine leakage when coughing and sneezing is most consistent with stress incontinence. It is atypical for UTIs to cause stress incontinence.  
✅ Hypermobile urethra secondary to pelvic floor muscle weakness:
 Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abnormal connection between the bladder and vagina:
Incorrect: This describes a vesicovaginal fistula. In patients with this condition, urine from the bladder can pass through the fistula, resulting in continuous incontinence. Pooling of urine in the vagina may be seen on a speculum exam. Risk factors include pelvic radiation and pelvic surgery. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has a normal speculum exam and none of the aforementioned risk factors.    
❌ Neuropathy causing impaired detrusor contractility:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes can cause autonomic neuropathy and an underactive detrusor muscle, resulting in overflow incontinence. The condition may present clinically as frequent urinary dribbling or a sense of fullness in the lower abdomen. However, this patient’s blood glucose is well-managed, as reflected through her HbA1c value. Moreover, the patient’s normal postvoid residual volume suggests that detrusor function is intact, and the bladder is able to empty normally.   
❌  Excessive urine production secondary to osmotic diuresis:
Incorrect: Patients with poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus can have elevated blood and urine glucose levels. This may impair water reabsorption in the renal tubules and result in polyuria. However, patients with polyuria would more likely present with symptoms of urge incontinence rather than the symptoms of stress incontinence described in this vignette.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of urinary incontinence. The patient has been waking up every morning with his underwear soaked in urine. He has noticed that if he does not take regular bathroom breaks at work, his underwear will have some urine in it. The patient urinates 8 to 11 times per day, with each episode producing small volumes of urine. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 167/108 mmHg. Physical examination reveals decreased pinprick sensation in the lower extremities. The patient is prescribed bethanechol. Which of the following complications is this patient most at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a neurogenic bladder secondary to long-standing type II diabetes mellitus. He is prescribed bethanechol, which is a cholinomimetic agent. The medication can cause peripheral vasodilation and subsequent reflex tachycardia.

Other adverse effects associated with the use of direct cholinomimetics includes central nervous system stimulation (e.g. anxiety, restlessness), miosis, bronchoconstriction, excessive gastrointestinal and genitourinary smooth muscle activity, and increased secretory activity (e.g. increased sweat production).

Option Analysis

❌ Constipation:
Incorrect: Bethanechol is a cholinomimetic that stimulates muscarinic receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and facilitates peristalsis. It can potentially cause diarrhea due to a sudden increase in motility. In contrast, constipation can be caused by anticholinergic agents such as atropine.  
✅ Reflex tachycardia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dry mouth:
Incorrect: Anticholinergic agents can cause dry mouth secondary to decreased salivary gland activity. In contrast, cholinomimetics such as bethanechol stimulate the salivary glands and increase salivation.  
❌ Muscle spasm:
Incorrect: Muscle spasms can be caused by cholinergic drugs that activate nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the skeletal neuromuscular junction (e.g., succinylcholine). Although bethanechol is a cholinergic agent, it acts only on muscarinic receptors and will not cause muscle spasms.  
❌ Mydriasis:
Incorrect: Mydriasis can be caused by anticholinergic agents such as atropine, which inhibit the contraction of the pupillary sphincter muscles. In contrast, the parasympathetic action of bethanechol on the eyes would cause miosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for urinary incontinence. The patient was recently prescribed oxybutynin; however, the patient has not had meaningful relief of symptoms. The patient states, “I still have to wear a diaper everyday. The medication you prescribed is not helping at all.” The patient is subsequently prescribed a medication that acts on the autonomic innervation of the bladder by relaxing the detrusor smooth muscle. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the aforementioned medication?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of urinary incontinence refractory to treatment with the antimuscarinic medication oxybutynin. The patient is subsequently provided with a medication that causes ß3-mediated autonomic innervation of the bladder, resulting in relaxation of the detrusor smooth muscle (e.g. mirabegron).    

Mirabegron is a selective ß3 agonist that is used to treat overactive bladder and resulting urinary incontinence. By relaxing the detrusor smooth muscle, the bladder is less prone to inadvertently emptying itself, thereby preventing the spontaneous passage of urine. It is often used as a second-line medication in patients who do not tolerate or respond to muscarinic antagonists.  

Side effects of mirabegron include hypertension, headache, and urinary retention. Thus, this medication should be avoided in those with severe, uncontrolled hypertension or those with frequent urinary tract infections.   

Option Analysis

✅ β3 agonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ M3 antagonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of oxybutynin, which has already been trialed in this patient without relief of symptoms.   
❌ M3 agonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of bethanechol, which is used to treat urinary retention, not urinary incontinence.   
❌ α1, α2 agonism:
Incorrect: α1 and α2 agonists include medications such as phenylephrine, which are not used to treat urinary incontinence.  
❌ ß2 agonism:
Incorrect: Medications such as albuterol or salmeterol are pure ß2 agonists and have no effect on bladder smooth muscles.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the office for two days with fever, chills, and perineal pain. The patient has had frequent urges to urinate and pain with micturition. The patient also reports mild lower abdominal discomfort. She is not sexually active. The patient was treated with an antibiotic for a presumed urinary tract infection 2 weeks ago. The patient’s medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows lower abdominal fullness and mild tenderness. Urinalysis is shown below. Urine culture and sensitivity demonstrates growth of >100,000 colony-forming units/mL of Escherichia coli resistant to gentamicin. Which of the following best describes the most likely underlying resistance mechanism of this bacteria? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Urinalysis   
 Specific gravity     1.020    
 Blood     trace    
 Leukocyte esterase     positive    
 Nitrites     positive    
 Leukocytes     100/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     4-6/hpf    
 Dysmorphic RBCs     Absent    
 Casts     none

choices.text: Mutation in protein in 30S ribosomal subunit
Chromosome encoded mutation in DNA gyrase
Production of a low-affinity penicillin-binding protein (PBP)
Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase
Replace alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan

questions.solution:
Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking the formation of the initiation complex and interfering with the aminoacyl binding site on the 30S ribosomal subunit. Ultimately, this results in misreading of mRNA and inhibition of translocation.

An important mechanism of resistance to aminoglycosides is the chromosomal mutation (methylation) in the gene that codes for the target protein in the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome. This mutation inhibits the ability of aminoglycosides to interfere with translation. Other common mechanisms include:

  •  Modification of the drugs chemical structure by plasmid-encoded phosphorylation, adenylylation and acetylation  
  •  Decreased permeability of the medication due to mutations in bacterial porin proteins.  


Option Analysis

✅ Mutation in protein in 30S ribosomal subunit :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chromosome encoded mutation in DNA gyrase :
Incorrect: Resistance to quinolone antibiotics is primarily mediated by chromosomal-encoded mutations that modify the bacterial DNA gyrase. 
❌ Production of a low-affinity penicillin-binding protein (PBP) :
Incorrect: Resistance to penicillins is caused by changes in the PBPs in the bacterial cell membrane.  
❌ Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase :
Incorrect: Decreased activity of bacterial catalase-peroxidase is the mechanism of mycobacterial resistance to isoniazid. Mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase activity is required to synthesize the active metabolite of isoniazid that inhibits the growth of M. tuberculosis. 
❌ Replace alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan :
Incorrect: Resistance to vancomycin is caused by a change in the peptide component of peptidoglycan from D-alanyl-D-alanine, to D-alanine-D-lactate.
